sites.title: Great Wall – Mutianyu Section
sites.summary: Well-preserved section of the Great Wall offering stunning mountain vistas and watchtowers.
sites.description_md:
# Great Wall – Mutianyu

The Mutianyu stretch of the Great Wall dates from the Ming dynasty and features crenellated battlements and 23 watchtowers. Cable cars and a toboggan ride provide access to this scenic section.

sites.title: Forbidden City
sites.address: 4 Jingshan Front St, Dongcheng, Beijing, China
sites.summary: Imperial palace complex with nearly 1,000 buildings that housed Ming and Qing emperors.
sites.description_md:
# Forbidden City

Also called the Palace Museum, this UNESCO World Heritage site served as the seat of Chinese power for over five centuries. Its halls and courtyards display imperial art and architecture.

sites.title: Temple of Heaven
sites.address: 1 Tiantan E Rd, Dongcheng, Beijing, China
sites.summary: Vast park and complex where emperors prayed for good harvests, featuring the Hall of Prayer for Good Harvests.
sites.description_md:
# Temple of Heaven

This Ming-era complex comprises the triple‑gabled Hall of Prayer for Good Harvests, Circular Mound Altar and Echo Wall. Locals practise tai chi and play music in the surrounding park.

sites.title: Summer Palace
sites.summary: Expansive lakeside retreat with pavilions, bridges and the Long Corridor.
sites.description_md:
# Summer Palace

Built as an imperial garden in 1750, the Summer Palace features Longevity Hill, Kunming Lake and ornate covered walkways. A boat ride on the lake offers tranquil vistas.

sites.title: Tiananmen Square
sites.summary: One of the world’s largest public squares surrounded by monuments of modern China.
sites.description_md:
# Tiananmen Square

Covering 44 hectares, Tiananmen Square is flanked by the Forbidden City, Great Hall of the People, National Museum of China and Mausoleum of Mao Zedong. Flag‑raising ceremonies occur at sunrise.

sites.title: Beijing Hutongs
sites.address: Various hutong alleys in Beijing, China
sites.summary: Maze of narrow lanes lined with traditional courtyard residences offering glimpses into local life.
sites.description_md:
# Beijing Hutongs

Beijing’s ancient hutongs showcase traditional siheyuan courtyard houses. Areas like Nanluoguxiang and Yandaixiejie brim with boutiques, cafés and street food.

sites.title: Lama Temple (Yonghe Temple)
sites.summary: Tibetan Buddhist monastery known for its incense‑scented halls and giant Maitreya statue.
sites.description_md:
# Lama Temple

Originally a palace for Emperor Yongzheng, this temple became a lamasery in 1744. Its main hall houses a 26‑metre sandalwood statue of Maitreya Buddha carved from a single tree.

sites.title: 798 Art District
sites.summary: Former factory complex transformed into galleries, studios and street art displays.
sites.description_md:
# 798 Art District

Once a Soviet‑built electronics factory, 798 has blossomed into a hub of contemporary Chinese art. Visitors explore galleries, cafés and outdoor installations.

sites.title: Ming Tombs
sites.summary: Valley containing the mausoleums of 13 Ming emperors along a sacred way lined with statues.
sites.description_md:
# Ming Tombs

The Ming Dynasty’s emperors were buried in grand tombs north of Beijing. Visitors walk the Spirit Way lined with animal and human statues and explore chambers at Dingling and Changling.

sites.title: Jingshan Park
sites.address: 44 Jingshan W St, Xicheng, Beijing, China
sites.summary: Man‑made hill offering panoramic views of the Forbidden City and Beijing skyline.
sites.description_md:
# Jingshan Park

Created from soil excavated for the Forbidden City’s moat, Jingshan Hill rises 45 metres. Climb to the Wanchun Pavilion for sweeping views of the imperial palace rooftops.
